item.title: George Floyd death: Violence erupts on sixth day of protests
item.description: Protests continue in cities across the US sparked by the death of George Floyd at the hands of police.

item.title: Coronavirus: Some primary schools reopen as parents remain wary
item.description: Classes resume for some pupils in England after 10 weeks but a number of schools will stay shut.

item.title: Coronavirus changes how doctors deal with death
item.description: Five doctors administering end-of-life care reflect on the current crisis.

item.title: Coronavirus: Queen seen in public for first time since lockdown, riding pony
item.description: The monarch is pictured riding outside Windsor Castle, where she is isolating with Prince Philip.

item.title: Christo: Bulgarian-born artist who famously wrapped landmarks dies at 84
item.description: The Bulgarian-born artist, known for his monumental projects, dies at his home in New York.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Our business can now get cracking' after lockdown
item.description: Outdoor markets and car showrooms in England are allowed to reopen from Monday amid the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: Belgian Prince Joachim apologises for Spanish lockdown party
item.description: Prince Joachim, who contracted coronavirus after attending a party in Spain, "regrets" his actions.

item.title: Hong Kong: Boris Johnson urged to form alliance over China security law
item.description: The UK should be leading the response to China's treatment of Hong Kong, seven former foreign secretaries say.

item.title: SpaceX Nasa Mission: Astronauts on historic mission enter space station
item.description: Nasa's Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken complete their 19-hour flight to the orbiting laboratory.

item.title: Durdle Door: Tombstoning continues despite three seriously hurt
item.description: Police say people have been seen jumping again from Durdle Door despite three people getting badly hurt.

item.title: George Floyd death: Thousands join UK protests
item.description: People chant "black lives matter" after the killing of a black man by police in the US.

item.title: The Papers: 'A million pupils stay home' as some schools return
item.description: Some primary school years in England returning and lockdown rules easing feature in Monday's papers.

item.title: Our masked identities: Cartoons of India's new normal
item.description: Cartoonist Priya Kuriyan documents how masks became prevalent in India - even before its lockdown.

item.title: How Venezuela's fuel crisis is hitting coronavirus victims
item.description: Venezuela's fuel crisis has been so acute that even funeral homes are struggling to transport bodies to the cemetery.

item.title: 'People use us to go to sleep to': Sudoku solvers become internet sensation
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world are watching these men solve Sudoku puzzles.

item.title: Coronavirus: The South African village preparing for Covid-19
item.description: For people in South Africa's rural areas trying to protect themselves from Covid-19, hand washing in clean water isn't possible.

item.title: UK weather in pictures: Sunny spring draws people outdoors
item.description: People flock to beaches and beauty spots to enjoy the warmer weather as some lockdown rules ease.

item.title: Candle scents inspired by pubs and other stories you may have missed
item.description: From social distancing dinner dates to candle scents inspired by pubs, here are some stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England in June, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: George Floyd death: Why do some protests turn violent?
item.description: In the US, peaceful protests over police violence have escalated into widespread riots and looting.

item.title: Remote working: How cities might change if we worked from home more
item.description: Our homes, transport and city-centre spaces would change if we worked from home for good.

item.title: Russia and Turkey risk turning Libya into another Syria
item.description: Gen Haftar's forces have been beaten back from Tripoli but that does not mean peace is at hand.

item.title: Carly Fiorina's journey from secretary to CEO
item.description: The US entrepreneur started her business career answering the phone, and went on to lead Hewlett-Packard.

item.title: Dancing On My Own: The story behind Robyn's 2010 'sad banger'
item.description: The Swedish singer discusses her pop classic, and how she once became 'tired of the broken heart'.

item.title: In mid-Pacific with nowhere to land
item.description: A group of performers were halfway across the ocean in a 75ft boat when the pandemic erupted - leaving them with nowhere to go.

item.title: Championship season set to resume on 20 June
item.description: The Championship will restart on 20 June, more than three months after it was suspended because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Silverstone summer races given go-ahead by UK government
item.description: Formula 1 is given the go-ahead by the UK government to hold two races at Silverstone this summer, BBC Sport is told.

item.title: Sancho scores first hat-trick as Dortmund thrash Paderborn
item.description: England's Jadon Sancho scores the first hat-trick of his career as Borussia Dortmund thrash bottom side Paderborn.

item.title: Strict testing, isolation and no crowds - how snooker will return to live action on Monday
item.description: It has been more than two months since sport took place in the UK - BBC Sport gets an insight into how snooker will be the first live sport to be shown on TV.

item.title: Sancho, Thuram & Williams among athletes protesting against Floyd death
item.description: Jadon Sancho and Marcus Thuram join Serena Williams and others in protests against racism after the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Monday's gossip: Bayern Munich want to sign Sane & Havertz
item.description: Bayern Munich want to sign Leroy Sane and Kai Havertz, Chelsea lead race for Porto's Alex Telles, Tino Werner has decided on his future, plus more.

item.title: Match of the Day: Top 10 podcast - your best Premier League games revealed
item.description: See which game you ranked the greatest in Premier League history, after the topic was discussed on the Match of the Day: Top 10 podcast.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children will be the first to go back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus': Parents shamed for back-to-school choices
item.description: Parents of year six and year one pupils have been falling out over whether to send them back to school.

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Will I still get paid if I have to self-isolate? And other questions
item.description: Will employees still get paid if they are told to self-isolate? And other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe is it to get on a plane?
item.description: Many airlines are planning to resume flying, but they first need to reduce the risks of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: Coronavirus: Dental practices to reopen from 8 June
item.description: Dental practices in England have been told they can reopen from Monday, 8 June.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Fact-checking the row
item.description: Senior Conservatives are still questioning adviser's account of driving his family 260 miles during lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: How will contact tracing work in England?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What can you do in Scotland from Friday?
item.description: After almost 10 weeks of lockdown which restrictions are being eased - and which remain in force?

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Did he break lockdown rules?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser has responded to accusations that he broke lockdown rules - what did he say?
